Caesarea-Maritima.org Chronology: This chronology is adapted from the chronology used in The New Encyclopedia of Archaeological Excavations in the Holy Land
. This taxonomy is used in the catRef encoding to classify the testimonia according to the time period(s) of the events described, rather than the date of composition of the testimonium. For example, Josephus may describe events occuring well before the period of his writing.
Caesarea-Maritima.org Testimonia Typology: This typology defines three subsets of testimonia employed by the project and is used in the catRef below to further categorize a given testimonia record.

category.catDesc: A "direct testimonium" contains a word or phrase that is a direct reference to, or name for, the conceptual place Caeseara Maritima or its environs in part or in whole. When a "direct testimonium" also contains indirect references, the classification by type is nevertheless marked only as "direct".

An "indirect testimonium" makes only an indirect reference to the conceptual place Caeseara Maritima or its environs in part or in whole. This indirect reference may take the form of a common noun or may be implied by context.

A "toponymic testimonium" contains a toponymic epithet related to the conceptual place Caeseara Maritima or its environs. When a "direct testimonium" also contain a "toponymic testimonium", the testimonium is marked as belonging to both types. These two types do not always overlap and thus our data set also includes "toponymic testimonia" which are not "direct testimonia".

profileDesc.creation: This entry is taken from Life of Gregory the Miracle-Worker 905C-908D written by Gregory of Nyssa in 380-385 CE. This work was likely written in Pontus.

body.desc: Caeasrea Maritima is indirectly attested at Gregory of Nyssa, Life of Gregory the Miracle-Worker 905C-908D. This passage was written circa 380-385 CE possibly in Pontus.

Gregory of Nyssa was a learned theologian of the 4th century venerated as one of the so-called Cappadocian Fathers. Raised in a prominent Christian family in Pontus, he became bishop of Nyssa in Cappadocia in 372, while his famous brother Basil was metropolitan at Caesarea Mazaca. Among his many writings was a biography of Gregory the Miracle-Worker, who was remembered as the founder of the Christian community at Neocaesarea, the home of Gregory‚Äôs family, over a century earlier. The author shows little knowledge of the writings of his subject but seems to rely on local tradition, which in places gives an incomplete or distorted historical picture. In comparison to other sources on Gregory the Miracle-Worker‚Äôs experience as a student of Origen at Caesarea Maritima, Gregory of Nyssa highlights Firmilian‚Äôs key role as Gregory‚Äôs companion in spiritual instruction, and places Gregory‚Äôs commitment to God before his tutelage under Origen.

But such is the prologue to his life. What of the life itself? After having dashed through the entire curriculum of worldly wisdom, he met a certain Firmilian from the elite in Cappadocia, a man of comparable character, as he demonstrated later in life, who became the jewel of the Church of Caesarea (Mazaca). (Gregory) made clear to his friend the focus of his thought and his very life, that he was looking to God, and he realized that (Firmilian‚Äôs) devotion aligned with the same desire. He abandoned all devotion to worldly philosophy and travelled with (his friend) to the preeminent teacher of Christian philosophy at that time‚Äîit was Origen, whose great fame rested on his writings. Thus he displayed not only his love of learning and hard work, but also the restraint and balance of his character. Since he was filled with so much wisdom, he did not deign to employ another teacher for the study of divinity. When he had spent the period of time with his teacher appropriate to his studies, although there were many people inviting him and retaining him abroad, and thinking it a good idea (for him) to stay with them, he decided that he preferred the land that bore him above all others, and returned home. He brought in his manifold wealth and knowledge, which he imported like a merchant in all world pursuits who conducts business with a celebrated clientele.Adapted from Slusser 1998
